body.p: Thank you for resubmitting your work entitled “Conformational dynamics of the nucleotide binding domains and the power stroke of a heterodimeric ABC transporter” for further consideration at eLife. Your revised article has been evaluated by a Senior Editor, John Kuriyan, as well as by a member of our Board of Reviewing Editors, along with two peer reviewers. In general we think that you have shown that the new mechanism that you propose exists both in detergent micelles as well as in a lipid environment. To show this equivalence was the central criticism of the original review.
However, before the manuscript can be formally accepted, several minor issues, outlined below, should be addressed in a revised manuscript:

1) On the basis of the new experiments the authors emphasize how well the detergent and nano disc experiments agree. Although for many conclusions they indeed agree well, there are also very pronounced differences. The main difference is mentioned only in the Results section (and not in the Discussion): The stringent dependence on the inward-outward transition on the presence of substrate. This data clearly shows that the dynamics is different in lipid bilayers compared to detergent solution, and the authors should discuss this point in more detail (also in relation to relevant literature that similarly showed subtle yet important differences in the behavior of membrane transport proteins in detergent vs lipid, e.g., Hanelt et al Nat Struct Mol Biol. 2013 Feb;20(2):210-4.).

2) Although the authors explain their Gaussian method in the rebuttal, some questions remain: What does the expression “relatively unique” mean? Perhaps the crucial question is: can the reliability of the fits be quantified in a way that the reader (non-specialist) can understand? In particular, the authors mention that their method provides statistical tools, yet there does not seem to be a statistical evaluation of the data in the manuscript.

3) Related to the point above: Why is the noise in the DEER signals so different for the different mutants (e.g., Figure 1–figure supplement 4: compare 555/647 with 533/625). Does the noise affect the reliability?
4) In Figure 3 and also in Figure 4–figure supplement 4 the positions are labeled 55/147 in the structural overviews, but 55/146 in the distance plots. Which one is correct?
[Editors’ note: a previous version of this study was rejected after peer review, but the authors submitted for reconsideration. The previous decision letter after peer review is shown below.]

Thank you for choosing to send your work entitled “Conformational dynamics of the nucleotide binding domains and the power stroke of a heterodimeric ABC transporter” for consideration at eLife. Your full submission has been evaluated by a Senior Editor, John Kuriyan, as well as by a member of our Board of Reviewing Editors, along with two peer reviewers. We regret to inform you that after discussions between the reviewers the decision was made that your work will not be considered further for publication.

While all reviewers see the importance and also the novelty of your results, there is substantial concern regarding several technical aspects of your study. While some of these could be dealt with by providing further details and explanations of the experimental procedures, some of the criticism would require additional experiments. In particular, the potential influence of the detergent on the results of the measurements was a major concern during the discussion of your paper among the reviewers and editors. Showing that the results are also valid in a bilayer environment would probably take several months. Due to this concern as well as some other technical questions, it was decided that additional proof of the validity of the results in liposomes are required before the paper could be considered for publication in eLife. A detailed list of all comments of the individual reviewers is provided at the end – these comments are provided for your information, and have not been merged to reflect the final consensus decision among the reviewers.

Miahra et al have investigated the conformational dynamics of the ABC exporter BmrCD. Despite several crystal structures that have been solved of ABC transporters in different states, the mechanism that couples the hydrolysis of ATP to the translocation process of small molecules across the membrane is not understood. BmrCD is a heterodimeric ABC exporter with one functional and one impaired nucleotide binding site. By using spin label pairs and DEER measurements the authors show that in contrast to similar studies with the homodimers MsbA, three different orientations of the NBDs with respect to each other can be identified, depending on whether the NBSs do not contain a nucleotide, are trapped in the post hydrolysis state or are bound to a non-hydrolyzable ATP analog. Investigating these conformational states under ATP turn over conditions showed that the NBDs form asymmetric heterodimers with the degenerate NBS being in an ATP bound or post-hydrolysis state while the consensus NBS shows all three states. This asymmetry leads to a weaker coupling between the NBDs and their ATP hydrolysis cycle and the TMD conformations. In contrast, in homodimers there is a stronger coupling.

Based on these DEER measurements the authors propose a model that shows that the degenerate site most of the time binds ATP while the consensus site shows a much faster cycling between different states. This is clearly different from the model suggested for homodimers.

The data are well presented and report on an important mechanistic aspect of ABC transporter function. Such a detailed study of the asymmetry of the two nucleotide binding sites is new and of interest beyond the ABC transporter field.
A few remarks remain:

1) If the coupling between the ATP hydrolysis and the substrate transport is less strong than in homo dimers, it would be expected that more ATP molecules per transported substrate molecule must be hydrolyzed. Has this number been measured?

2) Measuring of the ATP hydrolysis of the different spin labeled mutants shows for some of them quite significant differences where for example basal and stimulated activity are almost equal (Figure 1–figure supplement 2). This should be discussed in the main text.
General:

I like the approach and the results look very interesting, but it is a missed chance that the authors have chosen to do all their experiments in detergent solubilized state of the protein. Membrane transporters require a lipid bilayer to function, and EPR is one of the few techniques that can be used to study structural and mechanistic details in the membrane. Similar EPR work is now done routinely in the membrane-reconstituted state. In particular, I am concerned that the apparent uncoupling between the events in the NBSs and the TMDs in BmrCD could be an artifact of the detergent solution. Validation of the results in lipid bilayers is therefore needed.
Method:

The authors use a home-made and unpublished method in which they fit Gaussians to analyze the DEER spectra. The new method appears to result in distance distributions that look very “clean” and distances that are well defined. I am not an expert on this part, but it seems to me that the new method should be validated/tested more rigorously. The comparison with the established methods, which the authors apparently have done, should be presented. How do the distance distributions look when the standard base-line corrections are used? The authors state that the number of Gaussians, the amplitude and the width are fitted: how do these parameters behave? Is there enough information in the data to accurately fit all these values?
Turnover conditions:

It is completely unclear why the authors have measured the DEER spectra at two timepoints (1 and 5 min) during turnover conditions. This would be understandable only if they are measuring under pre-steady state conditions. I find it unlikely that the conditions are pre-steady state, because from the Pi release rates it can be calculated that for all mutant pairs there is at least one turnover per BmrCD (7nmol/mg) per minute (even in the absence of Hoechst). In any case, why would one desire to measure under pre-steady state conditions? And if the authors are interested in this type of kinetics then two time points are certainly not sufficient. What happens between 1 and 5 minutes of incubation?
In Figure 5 the relevant conditions is 5 min plus Hoechst, and not 1 min without Hoechst. This condition must be added.

The authors state in the Results section: “while a significant population of the consensus NBS is in apo-like conformation, the degenerate site is predominantly in...” The authors should not have used 348-532 pair for this measurement, but rather the 392-552 pair. From Figure 2 it can be observed that the latter pair would be much more sensitive in detecting the apo-state of the degenerate site.

In this study, Machaourab et al measured distances between pairs of spin labels monitoring the movement of the nucleotide binding and transmembrane domains of BmrCD, a heterodimeric ABC transporters with one non-canonical ATP-binding site.

The results purport to depose previously unobserved structural intermediates of the NBDs arising from an asymmetric configuration of catalytically inequivalent nucleotide binding sites, that is, from the interactions of canonical and non-canonical NBDs with ATP and the TMDs. The authors make two major conclusions, but only one is stated in the Abstract, namely that the two-state transition of the TMD, from an inward- to an outward-facing conformation, is driven exclusively by ATP hydrolysis, the so-called power stoke; and that sequence asymmetry in the NBDs shapes the mechanism of energy transduction in ABC heterodimeric exporters. The authors come to this conclusion from their analyses of DEER measurements in BmrCD, and relate these data to earlier studies (theirs and others) of homodimers with two canonical ATP sites in the NBDs, chiefly MsbA. Many of these results are questionable or at least require explanation and refinement, as outlined in the detailed points below. However, the (un-highlighted) second major finding of this study relates to the models depicted in Figure 7, which shows cartoons for the distinctively different mechanisms that drive ABC heterodimers (Figure 7A) and homodimers (Figure 7B).

With respect to the DEER data described here, it should be made clear what these distances refer to. Are they the measured distances between the probes, or estimates of the Cα-Cα distances of the respective residues based on these measures? So for example, the Cα-Cα distance between BmrCD 555/647 based on the Sav1866 structure is around 37 Å; does the DEER distance for the Vi-trapped state of 45 Å reflect the additional distance added by the probe or does it reflect a greater Cα-Cα distance than predicted by the structure? This is quite an important distinction since a 7 Å difference from the crystal structure could reflect a semi-open NBD dimer.

Vanadate traps the transporter by mimicking the pentacoordinate transition state, such that the protein cannot progress from this state. However, it is not clear in what sense this conformation is “high energy”. Indeed, given the stability of the species, does it not represent a free energy trough? The authors should state in what sense the intermediate is high energy and what evidence there is for that contention.
“This suggests large relative movement between the two NBDs upon energy input that brings them closer together.”

The authors should be clearer as to the nature of this energy input. The impression overall is that the notion of high energy is used somewhat vaguely in order to suggest that the energy of ATP is used to induce NBD closure, which is a high energy state, but none of this is explicitly stated or explained. How for example can the trapped state be formed from ADP+Pi (i.e., without requiring ATP hydrolysis, as has been reported) if it is a high energy state and NBD closure requires energy from ATP?

Given that Tombline et al (2005) and others have shown that nucleotide is occluded in only one site in the Vi-trapped state, and that Siarheyeva et al (2010) have found that the non-occluded site is accessible, on what basis do the authors contend that the Vi-trapped state is equivalent to the closed NBD sandwich dimer observed in crystal structures?
Results section:
“This is in stark contrast to the ABC homodimer, MsbA, where ATP binding and HES trapping stabilize the same conformation? (Borbat et al., 2007).”

The reference does not appear to include data for the ATP-bound state. Moreover, Borbat (2007) only provides data for NBD residue MsbA 539, which is equivalent to BmrCD 533/625, which according to Figure 1B, also does not show any difference between ATP-bound and Vi-trapped states for this residue pair. In Zou et al (2009), DEER distances for residue 561, equivalent to BmrCD 555/647, were not reported for the ATP-bound state. Thus, it is not clear on what basis the authors claim that the difference in behaviour for these positions between MsbA and BmrCD are “stark”, and point to fundamental functional differences.

“These characteristics suggest that ATP binding, mimicked by AMP-PNP, nucleates the formation of an NBD dimer distinct from the canonical closed NBD sandwich observed in the crystal structures of nucleotide-bound MsbA.”
As discussed above, this is highly interpretive and based on questionable premises, and is thus not appropriate in the 'Results' section.
“This state has features of the closed NBD sandwich (stabilized by ADP-Vi).”

The results show that, with respect to the core subdomain, as reported by 533/625 immediately downstream of the H-loop, the NBDs remain the same distance apart regardless of whether ATP, ADP, or ADP+Pi is bound, and that positions 555/647 are moved relative to each other and also to 533/625 in the transition state, relative to the ATP and ADP-bound states. Since 555/647 residues are toward the C-terminal, this may reflect a functional flexibility of this region relative to the core of the NBD, rather than a starkly different conformation of the NBDs?

In some cases the choice of position to attach probes is mystifying. For example, position 533/625, according to homology with Sav1866, is usually a large hydrophobic residue, which is buried and engaged in interactions with the C-terminal helix as well as the hydrophobic core of the core subdomain. Attachment of a probe at this position appears likely to disrupt significantly the structure at this point, as also suggested by the fact that basal and substrate-stimulated ATPase are about the same for 533/625.

Position 461/552 is a highly conserved leucine, buried very near the active site. It appears likely that a probe at this point would either sterically interfere with the nucleotide binding pocket or require the protein to fold non-natively at this point to accommodate the probe when nucleotide is bound at the proximal site. Again, the functional data suggest significant disruption for this probe position. The authors should discuss the possibility that probe attached to positions 461/552 could impinge on the nucleotide-binding pocket.
Why were conserved buried residue positions chosen to attach probes, while in other cases far more suitable choices were made (e.g., 392/484)?
“While ATP binding, mimicked by addition of AMP-PNP, induces the formation...”

The authors have interpreted their DEER data as indicating dimerisation of the NBDs upon addition of ATP to the apo state. It is difficult to conceive how the NBDs could dimerise without inducing the inward- to outward-facing switch in the NBDs, and also how having done so, hydrolysis could then induce the TMD switch? NBD dimerisation while the TMDs remained in the inward-facing conformation would require the CHs to disengage from the NBDs, in which case no ATP hydrolysis signal could be transmitted to the TMDs. This appears clear. It doesn't seem sufficient to simply postulate “large independent movement” of the NBDs, when in terms of the crystal structures and the switch mechanism, such a thing appears impossible. In what structural scenario could this happen?

Surely the data show that under steady state transport conditions the degenerate NBS does not sample significantly the widely open state (Figure 4C), that the consensus NBS is predominantly within 25 Å of the fully occluded conformation (Figure 4B; 5min) and the extracellular separation (Figure 5A) all but never happens? As discussed above, the data for the 533/625 pair indicate that all the distance changes observed between ADP+Vi-trapped and ATP-bound and ADP-bound states must be due to local changes, since the 533/625 pair does not change between these states. 515/607 are located on the D-helix, 440/532 on the α3-4 loop, and 441/348 on the A-loop. These positions have been found in MD simulations to be highly flexible, undergoing significant (ie >10 Å) changes while the NBDs remain closed at one NBS. The picture that emerges from the present data is similar to that for P-gp in Verhalen et al, (2012), where the protein doesn't sample the widely apart conformation to any significant extent during normal cycling.
“No other short distance component is detected as would be expected if the NBS were structurally asymmetric...”

For the single mutant 350, the distance of 67 Å under nucleotide-bound conditions (Figure 6–figure supplement 2) is some 18 Å longer than the Cα-Cα distance between the residue pair in the closed NBD crystal structure. Given a Cα-Cα distance between 350-471 of 20 Å in the closed state, the middle peak distance in Figure 6B of 53 Å, when a similar correction of 18 Å is applied, comes to a Cα-Cα distance of 35 Å. This is an increase of 15 Å. Since rotations of the core subdomain of this magnitude have been observed in MD simulations of the closed Sav1866 NBD dimer, these results do not preclude the possibility that the intermediate distance in Figure 6B does not represent a semi-open asymmetric state of the NBD dimer. The peak distances for the single mutants do not match the peak distances in the double mutants. This should be explained.
“Thus, we conclude that the two NBSs are structurally equivalent during MsbA ATPase cycle.”

This is not sustained. Clearly, it is possible that the broad peak for the longest distance in Figure 6B in fact represents the combined signals for the longer distance in a semi-open dimer in which one core subdomain is rotated open (downward away from the ICLs and outward from the opposite helical subdomain) by a distance of around 15 Å. This possibility should be discussed.

For the detection of the TMD conformational changes, why were not equivalently located residues as those used for BmrACD used? Residue 158 appears to be located within the membrane. Also, given that the probes attached to position 158 would clearly point away from each other, the DEER distance for the outward-facing state is only around 8 Å greater, whereas as discussed above, additional distances added by the probe, according to the authors' interpretation, reached over 15 Å. In the inward-facing structure of MsbA, Cα-Cα distances for residue 158 are around 40 Å, exactly the same as in the outward-facing conformation. Why was this position chosen? Why does it change when the structures predict it doesn't? Does this not mean the results are at odds with the mechanistic interpretation derived from the structures?
“In contrast to BmrCD, the equilibrium distinctly favors an outward-facing conformation.”
How do the authors draw this conclusion?

“We propose that the distinct catalytic mechanism of heterodimers requires a less efficient coupling between the NBD and TMD, a 'conformational leak', to enable NBD movement without transmission to the TMDs.”

This proposal is fine as proposals go, but it suggests that heterodimers operate with a different or additional minor(?) structural conformational change in the non-canonical NBD than in homodimers, and that this change is not transmitted to the TMDs. Since not all movements of ABC NBDs could possibly be transmitted to the TMDs, except in a concerted and allosteric 'global' sense, the use of the term 'conformational leak' is difficult to sustain without further explanation? How can this be construed as a mechanistic step in heterodimers, yet be completely absent in homodimers?
“Our results can be framed in a model of how asymmetric ATP binding and hydrolysis in the NBDs drive transition of the TMDs between inward- and outward-facing conformations (Figure 7A).”
Unfortunately the points above significantly blunt the force of this finding; and it is difficult to sustain this model without clarification of the data. Refer also to the next and final comments.

“The mechanistic elements of ATP turnover for ABC heterodimers and homodimers are contrasted in Figure 7... Analysis of MsbA conformational dynamics reported previously (Dong et al., 2005, Zou and Mchaourab, 2009, Borbat et al., 2007) and extended here is entirely consistent with a model of turnover that invokes engaged and disengaged NBD states, symmetric NBS conformations, and tight structural coupling between the NBDs and the TMDs. We conclude from the comparative analysis of BmrCD and MsbA conformational cycles that the controversy regarding NBD disengagement versus constant contact (George and Jones, 2012) is a consequence of extrapolation of models between mechanistically distinct classes of ABC exporters.”

If I read the extract of text here and Figure 7 (A&B) correctly, the authors seem to be concluding that the mechanisms for ABC heterodimers and homodimers are different, a conclusion that I find extraordinary. Given that heterodimers have canonical and non-canonical ATP catalytic sites and homodimers have dual canonical sites, I take it that the authors are drawing a vast distinction between ATP binding, and very slow hydrolysis, in non-canonical sites, with rapid ATP hydrolysis in canonical sites, and that this separates the mechanistic pathways of in hetero- and homodimers as depicted in Figure 7. The representation of heterodimers as proceeding via a so-called “constant contact” model and homodimers by the so-called Switch model defies credibility in such a closely related family of transporters and for which the NBDs are the most highly conserved domains. This needs to be explained and justified in clear detail.

Although for many conclusions they indeed agree well, there are also very pronounced differences. Reviewer #2:
General:

I like the approach and the results look very interesting, but it is a missed chance that the authors have chosen to do all their experiments in detergent solubilized state of the protein. We agree and have added the requested lipid bilayer data. Distance distributions in the NBDs and TMDs, shown in Figure 7, validate the findings from detergent micelles. Method:

The authors use a home-made and unpublished method in which they fit Gaussians to analyze the DEER spectra. The new method appears to result in distance distributions that look very “clean” and distances that are well defined. I am not an expert on this part, but it seems to me that the new method should be validated/tested more rigorously. The authors state that the number of Gaussians, the amplitude and the width are fitted: how do these parameters behave? Is there enough information in the data to accurately fit all these values?

The use of Gaussians to analyze the EPR data is not new and is in fact benchmarked and reported in the literature. The proper references are in the Methods section (Sen et al. and Brandon et al.). It is an alternative to Tikhonov regularization with a number of advantages including the possibility of rigorous error analysis and the ability to fit the intermolecular background. The home-made program just implements these published and benchmarked methods. The figure below shows clearly the equivalence between the Gaussians approach and the more widely used DeerAnalysis program of Jeschke. Reviewer #3:

In this study, Machaourab et al measured distances between pairs of spin labels monitoring the movement of the nucleotide binding and transmembrane domains of BmrCD, a heterodimeric ABC transporters with one non-canonical ATP-binding site.

The results purport to depose previously unobserved structural intermediates of the NBDs arising from an asymmetric configuration of catalytically inequivalent nucleotide binding sites, that is, from the interactions of canonical and non-canonical NBDs with ATP and the TMDs. The authors make two major conclusions, but only one is stated in the Abstract, namely that the two-state transition of the TMD, from an inward- to an outward-facing conformation, is driven exclusively by ATP hydrolysis, the so-called power stoke; and that sequence asymmetry in the NBDs shapes the mechanism of energy transduction in ABC heterodimeric exporters. Many of these results are questionable or at least require explanation and refinement, as outlined in the detailed points below. This comment is confusing: we demonstrate the existence of such intermediates; not depose previous results. We note that the structure of TM287/288 is asymmetric at the NBS supporting our findings.

Are they the measured distances between the probes, or estimates of the Cα-Cα distances of the respective residues based on these measures? Therefore, we can only speculate that this comment is meant to clarify it for the general reader. Vanadate traps the transporter by mimicking the pentacoordinate transition state, such that the protein cannot progress from this state. However, it is not clear in what sense this conformation is “high energy”. Indeed, given the stability of the species, does it not represent a free energy trough? The authors should state in what sense the intermediate is high energy and what evidence there is for that contention.

The ABC transporter literature more than adequately describes the nature of the vanadate trapped species. Sharma and Davidson even refer to this state as the transition state of ATP hydrolysis that is by definition a high energy state. We preferred in our papers to re-name it “a high energy post hydrolysis state” in deference to the enzymology literature that reserves the word transition state to a fleetingly populated state. Our usage of the term implies that in the apo or substrate bound intermediate i.e., in the absence of energy input, the transporter cannot sample this conformation. ATP binding and/or hydrolysis lowers the energy of the HES as would be expected. In a way, this is a matter of semantics but it should not cause confusion since it is well described in the field and in our previous publications as well as in the first usage of the term in this manuscript.

The authors should be clearer as to the nature of this energy input. The impression overall is that the notion of high energy is used somewhat vaguely in order to suggest that the energy of ATP is used to induce NBD closure, which is a high energy state, but none of this is explicitly stated or explained. How for example can the trapped state be formed from ADP+Pi (i.e. without requiring ATP hydrolysis, as has been reported) if it is a high energy state and NBD closure requires energy from ATP?

We explicitly describe the energy input as driving the population of this high energy state. We repeatedly note that ATP binding, mimicked by AMP-PNP, does not lead to the formation of the NBD sandwich observed in the structures of MsbA and Sav1866. Thus there is no vagueness.

There is literature from ABC importers that addition of ADP and Vi (not Pi) can indeed stabilize the HES. As noted above, we do not agree that mechanistic elements determined for one class of ABC transporters should be generalized without direct evidence to another class, particularly when the canonical sequences of the NBD are divergent. Furthermore, it is identified through measurements at multiple locations that although there is some conformational change with the binding of the ATP analog AMP-PNP, the transition to outward-facing is dependent upon ATP hydrolysis which is described by the measurements in the presence of ATP+Vi.

Unraveling the structural mechanism requires high resolution structures of ABC exporters from different classes. This is well beyond the scope of this paper; but the lack of current understanding of this aspect does not constitute an argument to refute an unequivocal data set that clearly shows a level of uncoupling between the NBDs and TMDs.

As discussed above, the data for the 533/625 pair indicate that all the distance changes observed between ADP+Vi-trapped and ATP-bound and ADP-bound states must be due to local changes, since the 533/625 pair does not change between these states. 515/607 are located on the D-helix, 440/532 on the α3-4 loop, and 441/348 on the A-loop. These positions have been found in MD simulations to be highly flexible, undergoing significant (ie >10 Å) changes while the NBDs remain closed at one NBS. The picture that emerges from the present data is similar to that for P-gp in Verhalen et al, (2012), where the protein doesn't sample the widely apart conformation to any significant extent during normal cycling.

We disagree with the statement “all but never happens”. There is a measurable reduction in the population of inward-facing conformation but the equilibrium still favors this conformations. The reviewer reiterates his/her exclusive confidence in the 533/625 pair that he/she has critiqued as a “mystifying” choice for label attachment.

On the one hand, the reviewer argues against using the 533/625 pair because of its effects on function yet attempts here to use it as an anchor overriding three different sets of pairs that directly monitor the NBSs. The idea that one of the NBS remains closed is refuted by the 3 pairs monitoring it.

Again in this comment, the reviewer uses Pgp studies (Verhalen et al.) to interpret data obtained in an ABC heterodimer. Verhalen et al. exclusively use sites in the C-terminal region of the NBDs that the author roundly dismisses for 555/647. This is another example of the mechanistic reductionism that percolates the review and is not supported by direct data in the literature.
“No other short distance component is detected as would be expected if the NBS were structurally asymmetric...”

For the single mutant 350, the distance of 67 Å under nucleotide-bound conditions (Fig. 6 Suppl 2) is some 18 Å longer than the Cα-Cα distance between the residue pair in the closed NBD crystal structure. Given a Cα-Cα distance between 350-471 of 20 Å in the closed state, the middle peak distance in Figure 6B of 53 Å, when a similar correction of 18 Å is applied, comes to a Cα-Cα distance of 35 Å. This is an increase of 15 Å. Since rotations of the core subdomain of this magnitude have been observed in MD simulations of the closed Sav1866 NBD dimer, these results do not preclude the possibility that the intermediate distance in Figure 6B does not represent a semi-open asymmetric state of the NBD dimer. The peak distances for the single mutants do not match the peak distances in the double mutants. This should be explained.

The reviewer is correct on the origin of the deviation of the 350/350 distance but mistaken in applying the correction to the 350/471 distance. Given the orientation of the labels in opposite directions along the interspin vector, the approximately 15 Å deviation is expected at symmetry-related pair 350/350. The deviation at 471 is smaller of the order of 10 Å also consistent with the expected orientation of the labels. Where the reviewer argument fails is in arbitrarily applying the 18Å correction to the 350/470 pair. The correction to be applied should reflect the expected orientation of the labels that in this case is closer to 10 Å.

More importantly, if as the reviewer contends, there is a semi open asymmetric state of one of the NBS that contribute to the middle distance component, then the ratio of the short distance component to the intermediate will be drastically different. Specifically d1 should be being appreciably smaller than the d2+d3 peak. Experimentally, the 1:2 ratio reflects of the geometry of Figure 6B where the two NBSs are structurally symmetric.
“Thus, we conclude that the two NBSs are structurally equivalent during MsbA ATPase cycle.”

This is not sustained. Clearly, it is possible that the broad peak for the longest distance in Figure 6B in fact represents the combined signals for the longer distance in a semi-open dimer in which one core subdomain is rotated open (downward away from the ICLs and outward from the opposite helical subdomain) by a distance of around 15 Å. This possibility should be discussed.
We agree with the reviewer that the Apo MsbA structure is asymmetric vis a vis NBSs. The statement should exclusively refer to the nucleotide bound state. It has been edited to be more precise.

For the detection of the TMD conformational changes, why were not equivalently located residues as those used for BmrACD used? Residue 158 appears to be located within the membrane. Also, given that the probes attached to position 158 would clearly point away from each other, the DEER distance for the outward-facing state is only around 8 Å greater, whereas as discussed above, additional distances added by the probe, according to the authors' interpretation, reached over 15 Å. In the inward-facing structure of MsbA, Cα-Cα distances for residue 158 are around 40 Å, exactly the same as in the outward-facing conformation. Why was this position chosen? Why does it change when the structures predict it doesn't? Does this not mean the results are at odds with the mechanistic interpretation derived from the structures?

Although this comment is not relevant to the findings of the manuscript, we will respond to it since it contains erroneous statements. For the record, residue 96 of BmrCD in the TMD is structurally equivalent to MsbA 103 so the comment is not entirely precise in regards to TMD conformational changes. Furthermore, the reviewer is incorrect in asserting that 158 “has exactly the same distance” in the two structures. In fact, a distance change of about 4 Å is expected from the crystal structures. We have noted in the previous papers that our data suggest a larger conformational change in the extracellular side of MsbA.

With this in mind, it is not clear to us why the amplitude of the distance change relevant here. Residue 158 is not used for direct comparison with BmrCD. The points it reinforces are: 1) that ATP binding is the power stroke and 2) that under turnover conditions MsbA favors the outward-facing conformation.
“In contrast to BmrCD, the equilibrium distinctly favors an outward-facing conformation.”

p.italic: How do the authors draw this conclusion?

body.p: Under ATP turnover conditions, we observe a large population of outward-facing MsbA. Please see Figure 7 103 and 158 panels.

“We propose that the distinct catalytic mechanism of heterodimers requires a less efficient coupling between the NBD and TMD, a 'conformational leak', to enable NBD movement without transmission to the TMDs.”

This proposal is fine as proposals go, but it suggests that heterodimers operate with a different or additional minor(?) structural conformational change in the non-canonical NBD than in homodimers, and that this change is not transmitted to the TMDs. Since not all movements of ABC NBDs could possibly be transmitted to the TMDs, except in a concerted and allosteric 'global' sense, the use of the term 'conformational leak' is difficult to sustain without further explanation? How can this be construed as a mechanistic step in heterodimers, yet be completely absent in homodimers?

We do not suggest that the conformational change at the NBD is not transmitted to the TMD. We suggest that such transmission requires ATP hydrolysis. The “conformational leak” refers to the tightness of the coupling between the NBDs and TMDs. The distinct mechanistic step is upon ATP binding. The “conformational leak” is necessitated by the finding that the hydrolysis step is the power stroke in heterodimers while the ATP binding step is the power stroke for homodimers. This is clearly stated in the description of the model for Figure 7. We interpret this comment in the context of the final comment which highlights the reviewer’s adherence to the notion that all ABC transporters must employ the same conformational cycle, a view that is not supported by any explicit data in the literature.
“Our results can be framed in a model of how asymmetric ATP binding and hydrolysis in the NBDs drive transition of the TMDs between inward- and outward-facing conformations (Figure 7A).”
Unfortunately the points above significantly blunt the force of this finding; and it is difficult to sustain this model without clarification of the data. Refer also to the next and final comments.
We respectfully disagree. We believe we refuted the reviewer’s points above and re-iterate our model.

“The mechanistic elements of ATP turnover for ABC heterodimers and homodimers are contrasted in Figure 7... Analysis of MsbA conformational dynamics reported previously (Dong et al., 2005, Zou and Mchaourab, 2009, Borbat et al., 2007) and extended here is entirely consistent with a model of turnover that invokes engaged and disengaged NBD states, symmetric NBS conformations, and tight structural coupling between the NBDs and the TMDs. We conclude from the comparative analysis of BmrCD and MsbA conformational cycles that the controversy regarding NBD disengagement versus constant contact (George and Jones, 2012) is a consequence of extrapolation of models between mechanistically distinct classes of ABC exporters.”

If I read the extract of text here and Figure 7 (A&B) correctly, the authors seem to be concluding that the mechanisms for ABC heterodimers and homodimers are different, a conclusion that I find extraordinary. Given that heterodimers have canonical and non-canonical ATP catalytic sites and homodimers have dual canonical sites, I take it that the authors are drawing a vast distinction between ATP binding, and very slow hydrolysis, in non-canonical sites, with rapid ATP hydrolysis in canonical sites, and that this separates the mechanistic pathways of in hetero- and homodimers as depicted in Figure 7. The representation of heterodimers as proceeding via a so-called “constant contact” model and homodimers by the so-called Switch model defies credibility in such a closely related family of transporters and for which the NBDs are the most highly conserved domains. This needs to be explained and justified in clear detail.

We agree that the contrast between our quoted text and the reviewer’s rebuttal captures the crux of this review. The statement that our model “defies credibility” reflects a preconceived notion that all ABC transporters (exporters?) must share a common conformational cycle. There is simply no evidence for this contention. It is reminiscent of the early dogmatic view that ABC exporters and ABC importers must have a common mechanism, a dogma that is now all but debunked. We surmise that holding on to dogmas in the face of unequivocal data is what defies credibility. We anticipate that the clarifications and explanations will convince the reviewer of the veracity of our interpretation of the DEER data, a technique that is extensively used in the laboratory.
